results.headline: A Man, a Corpse and No Memory
results.capsule_review: Amnesiac janitor believes he is a secret agent. Entertaining he’s not.
results.summary_short: This could have been a wry parody of the “Bourne” movies, but the script isn’t savvy enough, and Cedric the Entertainer’s performance isn’t subtle enough. So it ends up being something at which a grown-up could safely drop a 13-year-old, rather than something parent and child would both enjoy.

results.headline: A 'Da Vinci Code' That Takes Longer to Watch Than Read
results.summary_short: Theology aside, "The Da Vinci Code" is, above all, a murder mystery. And as such, once it gets going, Ron Howard's movie has its pleasures. He and the screenwriter Akiva Goldsman have deftly rearranged some elements of the plot, unkinking a few overelaborate twists and introducing others that keep the action moving along. The movie does, however, take a while to accelerate, popping the clutch and leaving rubber on the road as it tries to establish who is who, what he's doing and why.

results.headline: A Future More Nasty, Because It's So Near
results.capsule_review: Insurance investigator's affair disturbs dystopian order. Strenuously inventive future filmed with a logy elegance.
results.summary_short: Michael Winterbottom, a prolific and stylistically promiscuous director tries his able hand at dystopian science fiction. The movie is thick with disquieting, not always coherent ideas about the effects of globalization on human intimacy.
